text: You can search knowledge articles using `type=KNOWLEGE_ARTICLE`
Hi, can someone please tell me the best way to deal with one level of tags / categories in blogs? My clients really needs 2 levels…i read that i is possible with hubDB…is this correct?

what exactly is it you’re trying to do?

a post can have multiple tags/topics so for example if you have to like nest tags you can easily fake it
hi Jon thanks for the reply! i would like to have “Events” as a Main Categorie and “internal Events” as a subcategory of that…for example
is this possible with hubl code?
There aren’t any cat / sub cat setups native to the blog, but yes you could theoretically make something like this happen in HubDB
does “theoretically”  mean that it is a lot of work and or hard to accomplish? i understand why there are not 5 levels, but 2 levels would really not hurt anyone, would it?
it becomes a question of what you really need to do and why
I recommend creating an “Events” blog
and just having all categories under it being their respective topics
so this would make “the entire” blog the “first level” and not the first level in the blog with a second level…correct?
for me it is really frustrating that i can´t even get arround this with custom coding…easily without having trouble
Yes, the blog would be something like /events then each category could have it’s own slug like /events/event-subcategory/slug-of-the-event
You can get around it with HubL - quite easily
ex: just have the blog have “events” topic and all of your other topics “internal events” … “external events” etc
Then in the template, when you want to display something, check for “events” in the topic_list and render it as a first-level breadcrumb or whatever
is “slug” here the same as tag? don´t trying to be picky on anything i am just confused, thats all :wink:..
you could then also look for “events” in the topic name and render ONLY topics that contain events if the topic “events” is found
slug would be any final url of a piece of content on the site
in this case, the actual url of the blog post
or “event”
sorry, have to go, thanks a lot for  your help Michael!!
Np - best of luck!

I guess I might not have the full picture but:
So barring any concerns about how the events are edited, and concerning only the data.

You could can do “sub-topics” by setting the actual name of the topics like this x_Main Topic_Sub Topic

Then when displaying you just use the replace function to strip out the x and can use split to get the first or second part of the topic name
then you could have all subtopics also have the topic x_Main Topic so you can loop through either the topics with the main topic or the sub topic as needed

That’s how the filtering for this page works <https://www.lamacchiagroup.com/our-work>
Each of the options on the side is just topics pulled from the listings and if they are x_type_Credit Union
it generates a checkbox for Credit Union.

I get this isn’t really what you’re trying to do it’s just an example of a similar execution using topics. What was cool about this was the client now has the control to add new checkboxes under type, building type, and features, just by adding a new topic to the blog posts. If you did it with topics/sub topics your client would then be able to create new topics and subtopics without needing your help(as long as you explain how the topic name works)
hi Jon thanks for all the great information! this really helped a lot!

Wasn't there suppose to be an update the import functionality for contacts where you import objects like contacts linked to companies and such? Also import just companies? Was this a TBA when this going to roll out or was it just for enterprise?
